ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course takes an in-depth look at bureaucracy. While there are many other courses at Yale which briefly mention this topic, PLSC 258 dedicates an entire semester to critically thinking about bureaucracy.
I learned about democracy and bureaucracy.
I gained a lot of knowledge about the bureaucracy and how it operates. I also learned a lot about how people interact with the bureaucracy like special interests and the community.
Basic understanding of a bunch of different theories of how the US federal bureaucracy works
I learned how to approach understanding the bureaucracy in a more holistic manner.  I also learned how to do usurp background information on how certain bureaucracies are formed.
The course was a survey on the features of the American bureaucratic system.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course is very much a student-led seminar which can have its pro's and con's. If student's are engaged, the semester will be filled with conversation-rich discussions and debates surrounding the course material. If student's aren't engaged, then the class may feel long at times. However, Professor Turner always did a great job of discussing the key themes associated with that week's readings.

Strength: Good professor
No weakness

I really enjoyed the blog post assignments. I thought learning about a specific agency was very fruitful. I think the discussion could have been better if it came a little bit more from the class and less from the instructor. It might have been helpful to have students partially lead class on some days with the discussion questions we came up with.
Interesting material but the class ultimately ends up being pretty theory heavy. Would love to have had more opportunities to try and apply the theory to case studies
I liked the idea of integrating a project throughout the semester. It's a fun way to mix learning and creativity and to also ease the "burden" of research.

The strength of the course are the readings which I found to be intriguing and well-selected. One weakness would be that Prof. Turner always spoke more than the students by the end of each seminar class, making it more difficult to have class-wise discussions.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Using the raise hand function was very effective! Although, we could have used slides more often.
It was well handled in the virtual format considering the circumstances
I liked the 5 minute breakout room intros with different peers as a way to facilitate getting to know others in the class better. Very successful approach!

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I enjoyed taking this course and would recommend it to any political science major's looking to fulfill their seminar requirement. I didn't know much about bureaucracy before taking this course and am now much more well-versed when discussing this topic.
1000% recommend
I would if you are interested in learning specific things about the democracy. The material is pretty dense at times but interesting if you remain engaged.

I recommend this course to students very interested in political science, democracy, and bureaucracy in the United States. However, for someone not particularly interested in this course of study, the material was not very engaging. I recommend taking this course only if you are passionate about the subject matter.
If you like the theory end of political science (with the variables and whatnot), you'll really enjoy this class. If you don't, this class won't live up to what it could be.
Yes! Well run class, knowledgeable instructor, great course material.

If you are interested in the American bureaucracy and how it works, this is the class for you. The discussions may be a bit lackluster, but the material is good. If you are not drawn by the topic, you may find yourself daydreaming during class.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: n/a
virtual seminar/small group discussions
